Award.AwardTitle: SaTC-EDU: EAGER: CFEAR: Cyber Forensics Education via Augmented Reality

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Creative educational and research programs need to be developed that will inspire young adults (also known as millennials) to pursue critical skills needed to drive our cybersecurity and STEM future and close the ever increasing cybersecurity talent gap. In this regard, educators and researchers must develop innovative curriculum incorporating emerging technologies, in addition to the theoretical content, to help cultivate and retain a highly skilled cybersecurity workforce. Along these lines, faculty and researchers at Metropolitan State University and the University of Minnesota propose to explore and investigate the use of Augmented Reality (AR) in imparting cybersecurity and forensics education and conducting related research; the major focus of the proposed work revolves around Smart- Glasses.

Creative ways to impart cybersecurity and forensics education through smart-glasses, related apps, and/or other AR devices will be explored using a Discovery (or inquiry-based) Learning approach. This mode of delivery will allow students to interact with cyber forensics theories in an innovative, interactive, and effective way, enhancing their overall live experience and experiential learning. This exploratory research work will be ultimately transformed into cybersecurity and forensics curriculum at the undergraduate and graduate level. The efficacy of AR and smart-glasses in attracting, motivating and retaining students (with special emphasis on minorities and women) in cybersecurity and forensics will also be explored. With the help of collected data [observations of first-person (students) videos (live or recorded) while performing various cyber forensics related tasks, pre- post-course tests and student satisfaction surveys], the proposed work will identify unique skillsets for future cyber forensics workers as well as deficiencies, and learning gaps. Various security and privacy issues of smart-glasses (hardware, software, and available applications) will be investigated. In addition, we will investigate case scenarios, exposing system vulnerabilities due to smart-glass? integration with other wearable devices such as insulin pumps or pacemakers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Motivated by the importance and the seriousness of the some of the challenges in the cybersecurityand forensics field, faculty and researchers at Metropolitan State University proposed to explore the use of Augmented Reality in innovative ways relating to cybersecurity,privacy, and forensics. 

Multiple experiments were done using Microsoft Hololens and following observations were made.

Experiment 1: 

A proof of concept application was developed and tested by both graduate and undergraduate students and experts in the field.Student satisfaction and usability inspection surveys were conducted and data were collected regarding the use of Microsoft HoloLens in cybersecurity education. Review of Augmented Reality (AR) Microsoft HoloLens application was conducted by technological experts to determine the problems that might occur when the end user (student) tests the applications in the classroom environment.The methodology was established, a post-test instrument was identified and background research was performed to conduct an educational experiment to compare learning outcomes from students using the Microsoft Hololens while performing a virtual lab vs those who did not use the augmented reality device. 

Experiment 2:

Mixed reality (MR) is a fairly new generation technology that allows the users to see and interact with virtually created objects augmented in the physical world. An educational experiment was designed and conducted to identify if there is any effect of using an MR device such as HoloLens in student?s learning versus using a more traditional approach of using just a computer. Students were evaluated based on post-test quiz scores. Results showed no statistically significant difference in learning outcomes. Students reported physical difficulties such as headaches and eye strain. However, they also reported they liked the device and would use it again in the future.

Application 1:

An Android-based proof of concept application was developed using Content Recognition to extract Indicators of Compromise (IOC), to aid in Cyber Threat Intelligence, while performing a lab. The application called IOCExtract for Smart Glasses can scan articles, feeds and other security related sources for IOC's. This application is very simple to use and has the benefit of being a hands-free and voice controlled application. A simple Flow Chart of the application functionality can be seen in the image. 

Application 2:

A more detailed HoloLens2 application was Implemented that demonstrates the following:

  • Show capability of the Hololens hardware and software suite
  • Real-time object recognition
  • Optical Character Recognition (OCR)
  • Voice transcription
  • Facial recognition

Publications:

  1. Andrew King Faisal Kaleem Khaled Rabieh (2020). A Survey on Privacy Issues of Augmented Reality Applications. 2020 IEEE Conference on Application, Information and Network Security (AINS). 
  2. Faisal Kaleem Portia Pusey Nikitha Kommera (2019). Augmented Reality Mobile Forensics Laboratory (AMFL).  Proceedings of The 10th International Multi-Conference on Complexity, Informatics and Cybernetics (IMCIC 2019).
  3. Nikitha Kommera Faisal Kaleem Syed Mubashir Shah Harooni (2016). Smart Augmented Reality Glasses in Cybersecurity and Forensic Education.  2016 IEEE International Workshop on CYBERSECURITY EDUCATION AND WORKFORCE (CEW).

Research Graduate Thesis:

  1. Nikitha Kommera (2017). AUGMENTED REALITY GLASSES IN CYBERSECURITY AND FORENSIC EDUCATION.
  2. Sabin Sapkota (2020). Use of a Mixed Reality Device in Education and its Impact on Students Learning.

Brief Summary

The use of Augmented Reality to create an alternative method for students to learn has potential to make learning more effective and efficient. Its purpose is not to overcome human intelligence or judgment with that of faster and more efficient machines. It will directly enhance human performance, allowing students to work faster and smarter, in full control of technology instead of being controlled by it. Creative ways of using the SmartGlass in cybersecurity education were explored and different applications of Smart Glasses were developed. Experiments showed mixed results.

Both experiments showed enthusiasm surrounding inclusion of augmented reality might be associated with the novelty of the augmented reality technology. Students showed high levels of engagement, felt they had control of the activity and could also explore topics on their own. Participants after using augmented reality had a positive impact on student learning experience, and showed increased learner outcomes at the end of the experiment. Evidence of the students?positive attitude towards AR was observed from the feedback forms collected after performing theexperiment. This feedback findings also suggested that students enjoyed the novelty of the AR technology and would likely take courses offered that the included the use of augmented realitysmart glasses like Microsoft HoloLens. 

The evaluation on student performance measured by the percentage of questions answered correctly indicated there is no difference between students using the HoloLens Device and a control group. Nonetheless, students did perform better overall, answering an average of 14 of the 20 question in the lab. Statistically significant findings isolating instructor did not provide significant findings, although the analysis showed instructor three had an impact on a greater learning objective score overall. No correlation was found between the time students took on the assessment and their percentage of questions answered correctly.
